Modular arithmetic is a system of arithmetic for integers, where numbers "wrap around" when reaching a certain value, called the modulus.

Given an integer m ≥ 1, called a modulus, two integers α and β are said to be congruent modulo m, if m is a divisor of their difference; that is, if there is an integer k such that: $$ α - β = k m$$


Any number divisible by 2 is called even, otherwise it's odd.

Prove that the sum and product of two even integers are even.

Let \(a=2n\) and \(b=2m\), where \(n\) and \(m\) are any integers:

$$\begin{align} a+b &= 2n+2m \\ a+b = 2(n+m) \end{align}$$

This proves that the sum is even.

$$\begin{align} a*b &= 2n*2m \\ a+b = 2(n*2m) \end{align}$$

This proves that the product is even as well.
Prove that the sum of two odd integers is even and that their product is odd.

Let \(a=2n+1\) and \(b=2m+1\), where \(n\) and \(m\) are any integers:

$$\begin{align} a+b &= 2n+1+2m+1 \\ a+b = 2(n+m+1) \end{align}$$

This proves that the sum is even.

$$\begin{align} a*b &= (2n+1)*(2m+1) \\ a+b = 4nm+2n+2m+1 \end{align}$$

Since \(4nm+2n+2m\) is even, then adding 1 will make it odd.
